title: Why does hybridization only occur in the central atoms? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hybridization doesn’t “occur.” Hybridization is a model we use to describe bonding. It’s sometimes convenient for us to hybridize the valence atomic orbitals of an atom. (Orbitals are, themselves, derived from a model.) The reason we only use hybridization for central atoms is that we don’t need it to describe peripheral atoms. However… It is perfectly OK to say, e.g. in formaldehyde [math]\mathrm{H_2C=O}[/math], that both the C and the O are [math]\mathrm{sp^2}[/math] hybridized. By VSEPR both atoms are trigonal planar. But for the oxygen, it really doesn’t matter much. See also my previous answers: Daniel James Berger's answer to Does hybridization exist in an isolated atom? Daniel James Berger's answer to Is hybridization real or just a theoretical concept? Daniel James Berger's answer to Which type of compounds can be explained by hybridization?

Hybridization does not occur, rather this is a way we use to explain the bonding in molecules. Also hybridization does not only occur at the central atoms, it also takes place at the peripheral atoms although theirs is of little significance with respect to the central atom, and that of the central atom is considered to be the hybridization of the entire molecule
